The group went on to become one of South Korea's most popular and best-selling

heading: Births
txt: Mikael Granlund, Finnish professional hockey player

entities.title: Mikael Granlund
entities.description: Mikael Antero Granlund is a Finnish professional ice hockey centre currently playing for the Nashville Predators in the National Hockey League (NHL). He previously played professionally in Finland with Oulun Kärpät and HIFK of the SM-liiga and in NHL as a member of the Minnesota Wild. He was selected by the Wild as the ninth overall pick in the 2010 NHL Entry Draft.

heading: Births
txt: Michael Chee Kam, New Zealand rugby league player

heading: Births
txt: Morgan Gautrat, American soccer player

entities.title: Morgan Gautrat
entities.description: Morgan Paige Gautrat is an American soccer player for the Chicago Red Stars of the National Women's Soccer League (NWSL), the highest division of women's professional soccer in the United States, and the United States women's national soccer team. She first appeared for the United States national team during a friendly against Korea Republic on June 15, 2013. She has since made 87 total appearance

heading: Births
txt: Reghan Tumilty, Scottish footballer

entities.title: Reghan Tumilty
entities.description: Reghan Tumilty is a Scottish professional footballer who plays as a defender for Scottish Championship club Raith Rovers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Porphyry of Gaza, Greek bishop and saint (b. 347)

entities.title: Porphyry of Gaza
entities.description: Saint Porphyry was bishop of Gaza from 395 to 420, known, from the account in his Life, for Christianizing the recalcitrant pagan city of Gaza, and demolishing its temples.

heading: Deaths
txt: Muirchertach mac Néill, king of Ailech (Ireland)

entities.title: Muirchertach mac Néill
entities.description: Muirchertach mac Néill, called Muirchertach of the Leather Cloaks, was a King of Ailech.

entities.title: Northern Uí Néill
entities.description: The Northern Uí Néill is the name given to several dynasties in north-western medieval Ireland that claimed descent from a common ancestor, Niall of the Nine Hostages. Other dynasties in central and eastern Ireland who also claimed descent from Niall were termed the Southern Uí Néill. The dynasties of the Northern Uí Néill were the Cenél Conaill and Cenél nEógain, named after supposed sons of Nial

entities.title: Ireland
entities.description: Ireland is an island in the North Atlantic. It is separated from Great Britain to its east by the North Channel, the Irish Sea, and St George's Channel. Ireland is the second-largest island of the British Isles, the third-largest in Europe, and the twentieth-largest on Earth.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roger II of Sicily (b. 1095)

entities.title: Roger II of Sicily
entities.description: Roger II was King of Sicily and Africa, son of Roger I of Sicily and successor to his brother Simon. He began his rule as Count of Sicily in 1105, became Duke of Apulia and Calabria in 1127, then King of Sicily in 1130 and King of Africa in 1148. By the time of his death at the age of 58, Roger had succeeded in uniting all the Norman conquests in Italy into one kingdom with a strong centralized go

heading: Deaths
txt: Manfred, King of Sicily (b. 1232)

entities.title: Manfred, King of Sicily
entities.description: Manfred was the last King of Sicily from the Hohenstaufen dynasty, reigning from 1258 until his death. The natural son of the Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II, Manfred became regent over the kingdom of Sicily on behalf of his nephew Conradin in 1254. As regent he subdued rebellions in the kingdom, until in 1258 he usurped Conradin's rule. After an initial attempt to appease pope Innocent IV he took

heading: Deaths
txt: Margaret of England, Queen consort of Scots (b. 1240)

entities.title: Margaret of England
entities.description: Margaret of England was Queen of Scots by marriage to King Alexander III.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fatima bint al-Ahmar, Nasrid princess in the Emirate of Granada (b. c.1260)

entities.title: Fatima bint al-Ahmar
entities.description: Fatima bint Muhammad bint al-Ahmar was a Nasrid princess of the Emirate of Granada, the last Muslim state on the Iberian Peninsula. A daughter of Sultan Muhammad II and an expert in the study of barnamaj, she married her father's cousin and trusted ally, Abu Said Faraj. Their son Ismail I became sultan after deposing her half-brother, Nasr. She was involved in the government of her son but was esp

heading: Deaths
txt: Roger Mortimer, 2nd Earl of March, English commander (b. 1328)

entities.title: Roger Mortimer, 2nd Earl of March
entities.description: Sir Roger de Mortimer, 2nd Earl of March, 4th Baron Mortimer, KG was an English nobleman and military commander during the Hundred Years' War.

heading: Deaths
txt: John de Vere, 12th Earl of Oxford, English politician (b. 1408)

entities.title: John de Vere, 12th Earl of Oxford
entities.description: John de Vere, 12th Earl of Oxford, was the son of Richard de Vere, 11th Earl of Oxford, and his second wife, Alice Sergeaux (1386–1452). A Lancastrian loyalist during the latter part of his life, he was convicted of high treason and executed on Tower Hill on 26 February 1462.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lorenzino de' Medici, Italian writer and assassin (b. 1514)

entities.title: Lorenzino de' Medici
entities.description: Lorenzino de' Medici, also known as Lorenzaccio, was an Italian politician, writer and dramatist, and a member of the Medici family. He became famous for the assassination of his cousin, Alessandro de' Medici, Duke of Florence in 1537. He was in turn murdered in 1548 in retaliation for his deed.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eric XIV of Sweden (b. 1533)

entities.title: Eric XIV of Sweden
entities.description: Eric XIV was King of Sweden from 1560 until he was deposed in 1568. Eric XIV was the eldest son of Gustav I (1496–1560) and Catherine of Saxe-Lauenburg (1513–35). He was also ruler of Estonia, after its conquest by Sweden in 1561.

heading: Deaths
txt: Maria of Austria, Holy Roman Empress, spouse of Maximilian II (b. 1528)

entities.title: Maria of Austria, Holy Roman Empress
entities.description: Archduchess Maria of Austria was the empress consort and queen consort of Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor, King of Bohemia and Hungary. She served as regent of Spain in the absence of her father Emperor Charles V from 1548 until 1551, and in the absence of her brother Philip II, from 1558 to 1561.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Still, English bishop (b. 1543)

entities.title: John Still
entities.description: John Still, Bishop of Bath and Wells, enjoyed considerable fame as an English preacher and disputant. He was formerly reputed to be the author of an early English comedy drama: Gammer Gurton's Needle.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antonio Possevino, Italian priest and diplomat (b. 1533)

entities.title: Antonio Possevino
entities.description: Antonio Possevino was a Jesuit protagonist of Counter Reformation as a papal diplomat and a Jesuit controversialist, encyclopedist and bibliographer. He acted as papal legate and the first Jesuit to visit Moscow, vicar general of Sweden, Denmark and northern islands, Muscovy, Livonia, Rus, Hungary, Pomerania, Saxony between 1578 and 1586.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anna Vasa of Sweden, Polish and Swedish princess (b. 1568)

entities.title: Anna Vasa of Sweden
entities.description: Anna Vasa of Sweden was a Polish and Swedish princess, starosta of Brodnica and Golub. She was the youngest child of King John III of Sweden and Catherine Jagiellon. She was close to her brother Sigismund Vasa, King of Poland (1587–1632) and King of Sweden (1592–99). Raised a Catholic, Anna converted to Lutheranism in 1584 which made her ineligible bride for many of Europe's Catholic royals and sh

heading: Deaths
txt: William Brade, English violinist and composer (b. 1560)

entities.title: William Brade
entities.description: William Brade was an English composer, violinist, and viol player of the late Renaissance and early Baroque eras, mainly active in northern Germany. He was the first Englishman to write a canzona, an Italian form, and probably the first to write a piece for solo violin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Claude Gaspard Bachet de Méziriac, French mathematician and linguist (b. 1581)

entities.title: Claude Gaspard Bachet de Méziriac
entities.description: Claude Gaspard Bachet de Méziriac was a French mathematician, linguist, poet and classics scholar born in Bourg-en-Bresse, at that time belonging to Duchy of Savoy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas d'Urfey, English poet and playwright (b. 1653)

entities.title: Thomas d'Urfey
entities.description: Thomas D'Urfey was an English writer and wit. He composed plays, songs, and poetry, in addition to writing jokes. He was an important innovator and contributor in the evolution of the Ballad opera.

heading: Deaths
txt: Maximilian II Emanuel, Elector of Bavaria (b. 1662)

entities.title: Maximilian II Emanuel, Elector of Bavaria
entities.description: Maximilian II, also known as Max Emanuel or Maximilian Emanuel, was a Wittelsbach ruler of Bavaria and a Prince-elector of the Holy Roman Empire. He was also the last governor of the Spanish Netherlands and duke of Luxembourg. An able soldier, his ambition led to conflicts that limited his ultimate dynastic achievements.

heading: Deaths
txt: Giuseppe Tartini, Italian violinist and composer (b. 1692)

entities.title: Giuseppe Tartini
entities.description: Giuseppe Tartini was an Italian Baroque composer and violinist born in the Republic of Venice.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joshua Rowley, English admiral (b. 1730)

entities.title: Joshua Rowley
entities.description: Vice-Admiral Sir Joshua Rowley, 1st Baronet (1734–1790) was the fourth son of Admiral Sir William Rowley. Sir Joshua was from an ancient English family, originating in Staffordshire (England) and was born on 1 May 1734. Rowley served with distinction in a number of battles throughout his career and was highly praised by his contemporaries. Unfortunately whilst his career was often active he did no

heading: Deaths
txt: Esek Hopkins, American admiral (b. 1718)

entities.title: Esek Hopkins
entities.description: Commodore Esek Hopkins was an American naval officer and slave trader. Hopkins was the only Commander in Chief of the Continental Navy during the American Revolutionary War. He was also an accomplished merchant captain and privateer. He is noted for his successful raid on the British port of Providence, in the Bahamas, and capturing large stores of military supplies.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas-Alexandre Dumas, Haitian-French general (b. 1762)

entities.title: Thomas-Alexandre Dumas
entities.description: Thomas-Alexandre Dumas Davy de la Pailleterie was a French general in Revolutionary France. With Toussaint Louverture and Abram Petrovich Gannibal in Imperial Russia, Thomas-Alexandre Dumas was as a high-ranking man of African descent leading a European army. He was the first person of color in the French military to become brigadier general, divisional general, and general-in-chief of a French ar

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert R. Livingston, American lawyer and politician, 1st United States Secretary of Foreign Affairs (b. 1746)

entities.title: Robert R. Livingston (chancellor)
entities.description: Robert Robert Livingston was an American lawyer, politician, diplomat from New York, and a Founding Father of the United States. He was known as "The Chancellor", after the high New York state legal office he held for 25 years. He was a member of the Committee of Five that drafted the Declaration of Independence, along with Thomas Jefferson, Benjamin Franklin, John Adams, and Roger Sherman. Living

entities.title: United States Secretary of Foreign Affairs

heading: Deaths
txt: Prince Josias of Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld (b. 1737)

entities.title: Prince Josias of Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld
entities.description: Prince Frederick Josias of Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld was an Austrian nobleman and military general.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph de Maistre, French lawyer and diplomat (b. 1753)

entities.title: Joseph de Maistre
entities.description: Joseph-Marie, comte de Maistre was a Savoyard philosopher, writer, lawyer and diplomat who advocated social hierarchy and monarchy in the period immediately following the French Revolution. Despite his close personal and intellectual ties with France, Maistre was throughout his life a subject of the Kingdom of Sardinia, which he served as a member of the Savoy Senate (1787–1792), ambassador to Rus

heading: Deaths
txt: Sybil Ludington, American heroine of the American Revolutionary War (b. 1761)

entities.title: Sybil Ludington
entities.description: Sybil Ludington was a heroine of the American Revolutionary War. On April 26, 1777, at age 16, she made an all-night horseback ride to alert militia forces in the towns of Putnam County, New York, and Danbury, Connecticut, of the approach of British forces.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis-Hippolyte Lafontaine, Canadian jurist and politician, 3rd Premier of Canada East (b. 1807)

entities.title: Louis-Hippolyte Lafontaine
entities.description: Sir Louis-Hippolyte Ménard dit La Fontaine, 1st Baronet, KCMG was a Canadian politician who served as the first Premier of the United Province of Canada and the first head of a responsible government in Canada. He was born in Boucherville, Lower Canada in 1807. A jurist and statesman, La Fontaine was first elected to the Legislative Assembly of Lower Canada in 1830. He was a supporter of Papineau

entities.title: List of Joint Premiers of the Province of Canada
entities.description: This is a list of the Joint Premiers of the Province of Canada, who were the heads of government of the Province of Canada from the 1841 unification of Upper Canada and Lower Canada until Confederation in 1867.

heading: Deaths
txt: Afzal-ud-Daulah, Asaf Jah V, 5th Nizam of Hyderabad State

entities.title: Afzal-ud-Daulah
entities.description: Afzal ad-Dawlah, Asaf Jah V Mir Tahniyath Ali Khan Siddiqi was the ruling Nizam of Hyderabad, India, from 1857 to 1869.

entities.title: Nizam
entities.description: The Nizams were the 18th-through-20th-century rulers of Hyderabad. Nizam of Hyderabad was the title of the monarch of the Hyderabad State. Nizam, shortened from Nizam-ul-Mulk, meaning Administrator of the Realm, was the title inherited by Asaf Jah I. He was the viceroy of the Great Mughal in the Deccan, the premier courtier in Mughal India in 1724, and the founding "Nizam of Hyderabad".

entities.title: Hyderabad State
entities.description: Hyderabad State, also known as Hyderabad Deccan, was an Indian princely state located in the south-central region of India with its capital at the city of Hyderabad. It is now divided into the state of Telangana, the Hyderabad-Karnataka region of Karnataka, and the Marathwada region of Maharashtra.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexandros Koumoundouros, Greek lawyer and politician, 56th Prime Minister of Greece (b. 1817)

entities.title: Alexandros Koumoundouros
entities.description: Alexandros Koumoundouros was a Greek politician. Born in Kampos, on the Messenian side of the Mani Peninsula, he was the son of Spyridon-Galanis Koumoundouros, the bey of the area during the last period of the administration of the region by the Ottoman Empire.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Greece
entities.description: The prime minister of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to as the prime minister of Greece, is the head of government of the Hellenic Republic and the leader of the Greek Cabinet. The incumbent prime minister is Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who took office on 8 July 2019.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anandi Gopal Joshi, First Indian women physician (b. 1865)

entities.title: Anandi Gopal Joshi
entities.description: Anandibai Gopalrao Joshi or A G Joshi was one of the first Indian female practitioners of western medicine, alongside Kadambini Ganguly. She was the first woman from the erstwhile Bombay presidency of India to study and graduate with a two-year degree in western medicine in the United States. She was also referred to as Anandibai Joshi and Anandi Gopal Joshi.

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl Davydov, Russian cellist and composer (b. 1838)

entities.title: Karl Davydov
entities.description: Karl Yulievich Davydov was a Russian cellist of great renown during his time, and described by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky as the "czar of cellists". He was also a composer, mainly for the cello.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Jordan Gatling, American engineer, invented the Gatling gun (b. 1818)

entities.title: Richard Jordan Gatling
entities.description: Richard Jordan Gatling was an American inventor best known for his invention of the Gatling gun, which is considered to be the first successful machine gun.

entities.title: Gatling gun
entities.description: The Gatling gun is a rapid-firing multiple-barrel firearm invented in 1861 by Richard Jordan Gatling. It is an early machine gun and a forerunner of the modern electric motor-driven rotary cannon.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Lanfray, Swiss convicted murderer (b. 1874)

entities.title: Jean Lanfray
entities.description: Jean Lanfray, a labourer who was French by birth but living in Switzerland, was convicted of murdering his pregnant wife and two children in a drunken rage on the afternoon of 28 August 1905 in Commugny, Switzerland. It was later revealed by police that he had drunk an excessive amount of wine and hard liquors that morning, along with two ounces of absinthe. However, due to the moral panic against

heading: Deaths
txt: Felix Draeseke, German composer and academic (b. 1835)

entities.title: Felix Draeseke
entities.description: Felix August Bernhard Draeseke was a composer of the "New German School" admiring Franz Liszt and Richard Wagner. He wrote compositions in most forms including eight operas and stage works, four symphonies, and much vocal and chamber music.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Menger, Polish-Austrian economist and academic (b. 1840)

entities.title: Carl Menger
entities.description: Carl Menger was an Austrian economist and the founder of the Austrian School of economics. Menger contributed to the development of the theory of marginalism, which rejected the cost-of-production theories of value, such as were developed by the classical economists such as Adam Smith and David Ricardo. As a departure from such, he would go on to call his resultant perspective, the "Subjective The

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Whiton Calkins, American philosopher and psychologist (b. 1863)

entities.title: Mary Whiton Calkins
entities.description: Mary Whiton Calkins was an American philosopher and psychologist. As a psychologist, she taught at Wellesley College for many years and conducted research on dreams and memory. Calkins was the first woman to become president of the American Psychological Association and the American Philosophical Association.

heading: Deaths
txt: Otto Wallach, German chemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1847)

entities.title: Otto Wallach
entities.description: Otto Wallach was a German chemist and recipient of the 1910 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his work on alicyclic compounds.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt:
February 26 Incident:
Takahashi Korekiyo, Japanese accountant and politician, 20th Prime Minister of Japan (b. 1854)
Saitō Makoto, Japanese admiral and politician, 30th Prime Minister of Japan (b. 1858)
Jōtarō Watanabe, Japanese general (b. 1874)

entities.title: February 26 Incident
entities.description: The February 26 Incident  was an attempted coup d'état in the Empire of Japan on 26 February 1936. It was organized by a group of young Imperial Japanese Army (IJA) officers with the goal of purging the government and military leadership of their factional rivals and ideological opponents.

heading: Deaths
txt: Theodor Eicke, German general (b. 1892)

entities.title: Theodor Eicke
entities.description: Theodor Eicke was a German SS functionary during the Nazi era. He was one of the key figures in the development of Nazi concentration camps during the Holocaust.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sándor Szurmay, Minister of Defence of the Hungarian portion of Austria-Hungary (b. 1860)

entities.title: Sándor Szurmay
entities.description: Vitéz Baron Sándor Szurmay de Uzsok was a Hungarian military officer and politician, who served as Minister of Defence for the Hungarian portion of the Dual Monarchy of Austria-Hungary between 1917 and 1918.

heading: Deaths
txt: Heinrich Häberlin, Swiss judge and politician, President of the Swiss National Council (b. 1868)

entities.title: Heinrich Häberlin
entities.description: Heinrich Häberlin was a Swiss politician, judge and member of the Swiss Federal Council (1920–1934).

entities.title: List of Presidents of the National Council of Switzerland
entities.description: The President of the National Council of Switzerland presides over the National Council and Federal Assembly. The National Council President is often colloquially referred to as the "highest Swiss person", as the highest ranking person subject to the people's vote. However, this is an honorary title and the president is not the head of state. The head of state is the Federal Council). In the offic

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Lauder, Scottish comedian and singer (b. 1870)

entities.title: Harry Lauder
entities.description: Sir Henry Lauder was a Scottish singer and comedian popular in both music hall and vaudeville theatre traditions; he achieved international success.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sabiha Kasimati, Albanian ichthyologist (b. 1912) executed with 20 others

entities.title: Sabiha Kasimati
entities.description: Sabiha Kasimati was an Albanian ichthyologist and dissident of the communist regime in Albania. She was shot, one of the victims of the regime of Enver Hoxha – with whom she had gone to school.

entities.title: 1951 executions in Albania
entities.description: The People's Republic of Albania executed 22 intellectuals without trial on 26 February 1951, as ordered by Enver Hoxha. They were accused of bombing the Soviet embassy in Tirana. The victims were 21 males and one female. One day earlier, Jonuz Kaceli was killed while accused of the same crime. It was the first time the Agitation and Propaganda law was used.

heading: Deaths
txt: Theodoros Pangalos, Greek general and politician, President of Greece (b. 1878)

entities.title: Theodoros Pangalos (general)
entities.description: Lieutenant General Theodoros Pangalos was a Greek general, politician and dictator. A distinguished staff officer and an ardent Venizelist and anti-royalist, Pangalos played a leading role in the September 1922 revolt that deposed King Constantine I and in the establishment of the Second Hellenic Republic. In June 1925 Pangalos staged a bloodless coup, and his assumption of power was recognized by

entities.title: President of Greece
entities.description: The president of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to in English as the president of Greece, is the head of state of Greece. The president is elected by the Hellenic Parliament; the role has been mainly ceremonial since the 1986 constitutional reform. The office was formally established by the Constitution of Greece in 1975, but has antecedents in the Second Hellenic Republic of 1924–19

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl Albiker, German sculptor, lithographer, and educator (b. 1878)

entities.title: Karl Albiker
entities.description: Karl Albiker was a German sculptor, lithographer and teacher of fine arts. Albiker studied with Auguste Rodin in Paris. From 1919 to 1945 he was a professor at the Dresden Academy of Fine Arts. His monumental statues, like those of Georg Kolbe, reflected National Socialist heroic realism. Albiker created the relay racers for Berlin's Reich Sports Field and various war monuments, including those i

heading: Deaths
txt: Mohammed V of Morocco (b. 1909)

heading: Deaths
txt: Vinayak Damodar Savarkar, Indian poet and politician (b. 1883)

entities.title: Vinayak Damodar Savarkar
entities.description: Vinayak Damodar Savarkar, commonly known as  Swatantryaveer Savarkar or simply  Veer Savarkar in Marathi language, was an Indian independence activist and politician who formulated the Hindu nationalist philosophy of Hindutva. He was a leading personality in the Hindu Mahasabha.

heading: Deaths
txt: Levi Eshkol, Israeli soldier and politician, 3rd Prime Minister of Israel (b. 1895)

entities.title: Levi Eshkol
entities.description: Levi Eshkol was an Israeli statesman who served as the third Prime Minister of Israel from 1963 until his death from a heart attack in 1969. A founder of the Israeli Labor Party, he served in numerous senior roles, including Minister of Defense (1963–1967) and Minister of Finance (1952–1963).

entities.title: Prime Minister of Israel
entities.description: The prime minister of Israel is the head of government and chief executive of Israel.

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl Jaspers, German-Swiss psychiatrist and philosopher (b. 1883)

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Aickman, English author and activist (b. 1914)

entities.title: Robert Aickman
entities.description: Robert Fordyce Aickman was an English writer and conservationist. As a conservationist, he co-founded the Inland Waterways Association, a group which has preserved from destruction and restored England's inland canal system. As a writer, he is best known for his supernatural fiction, which he described as "strange stories".

heading: Deaths
txt: Howard Hanson, American composer, conductor, and educator (b. 1896)

heading: Deaths
txt: Tjalling Koopmans, Dutch-American economist and mathematician, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1910)

entities.title: Tjalling Koopmans
entities.description: Tjalling Charles Koopmans was a Dutch-American mathematician and economist. He was the joint winner with Leonid Kantorovich of the 1975 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for his work on the theory of the optimum allocation of resources. Koopmans showed that on the basis of certain efficiency criteria, it is possible to make important deductions concerning optimum price systems.

entities.title: Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences
entities.description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences, officially the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel, is an economics prize administered by the Nobel Foundation. While it is not one of the Nobel Prizes, which were established by Alfred Nobel's will in 1895, it is commonly referred to as the Nobel Prize in Economics. The prize was established in 1968 by a donation fr

heading: Deaths
txt: Roy Eldridge, American trumpet player (b. 1911)

entities.title: Roy Eldridge
entities.description: David Roy Eldridge, nicknamed "Little Jazz", was an American jazz trumpet player. His sophisticated use of harmony, including the use of tritone substitutions, his virtuosic solos exhibiting a departure from the dominant style of jazz trumpet innovator Louis Armstrong, and his strong impact on Dizzy Gillespie mark him as one of the most influential musicians of the swing era and a precursor of beb

heading: Deaths
txt: Constance Ford, American model and actress (b. 1923)

entities.title: Constance Ford
entities.description: Constance Ford was an American actress and model. She is best known for her long-running role as Ada Hobson on the daytime soap opera Another World.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Hicks, American comedian (b. 1961)

entities.title: Bill Hicks
entities.description: William Melvin Hicks was an American stand-up comedian, social critic, satirist, and musician. His material—encompassing a wide range of social issues including religion, politics, and philosophy—was controversial and often steeped in dark comedy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jack Clayton, English director and producer (b. 1921)

entities.title: Jack Clayton
entities.description: Jack Clayton was a British film director and producer who specialised in bringing literary works to the screen.

heading: Deaths
txt: David Doyle, American actor (b. 1929)

entities.title: David Doyle (actor)
entities.description: David Fitzgerald Doyle was an American actor. He was best known for his portrayal of John Bosley on the 1970s TV series Charlie's Angels. Doyle and Jaclyn Smith were the only actors to appear in every episode of the show.

heading: Deaths
txt: Theodore Schultz, American economist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1902)

entities.title: Theodore Schultz
entities.description: Theodore William Schultz was an American economist and chairman of the University of Chicago Department of Economics. Schultz rose to national prominence after winning the 1979 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences.

entities.title: Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences
entities.description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences, officially the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel, is an economics prize administered by the Nobel Foundation. While it is not one of the Nobel Prizes, which were established by Alfred Nobel's will in 1895, it is commonly referred to as the Nobel Prize in Economics. The prize was established in 1968 by a donation fr

heading: Deaths
txt: George L. Street III, American captain, Medal of Honor recipient (b. 1913)

entities.title: George L. Street III
entities.description: George Levick Street III was a submariner in the United States Navy. He received the Medal of Honor during World War II.

entities.title: Medal of Honor
entities.description: The Medal of Honor (MOH) is the United States government's highest and most prestigious military decoration that may be awarded to recognize American soldiers, sailors, marines, airmen, Space Force guardians, and coast guardsmen who have distinguished themselves by acts of valor. The medal is normally awarded by the President of the United States, but as it is presented "in the name of the United

heading: Deaths
txt: Lawrence Tierney, American actor (b. 1919)

entities.title: Lawrence Tierney
entities.description: Lawrence James Tierney was an American film and television actor who is best known for his many screen portrayals of mobsters and tough guys, roles that mirrored his own frequent brushes with the law. In 2005, film critic David Kehr of The New York Times described "the hulking Tierney" as "not so much an actor as a frightening force of nature".

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Joseph Wapner
entities.description: Joseph Albert Wapner (November 15, 1919 – February 26, 2017) was an American judge and television personality. He was the first presiding judge of the ongoing reality court show The People's Court. The court show's first run in syndication, with Wapner presiding as judge, lasted from 1981 to 1993, for 12 seasons and 2,484 episodes.
